original_question: Why do I feel like a different person when I am angry?

lesson.subject: philosophy_core
lesson.title: Mind Seeds: Thoughts, Feelings, and You
lesson.description: An early mind-and-self lane that helps you notice thoughts, feelings, dreams, imagination, and what makes you feel like the same person over time.

content.spine_position: Begins in Kâ??8 as questions about thoughts, feelings, and 'me'; becomes philosophy of mind and personal identity in high school and undergrad; connects to cognitive science and consciousness studies at advanced levels.
prepares_for: Philosophy of mind and cognitive science.
Metaphysics of personal identity and time.
kid_core_explanations: Your mind holds your thoughts, feelings, memories, and daydreams.
Feelings (like happy, sad, angry, excited) are part of you, but they can change.
You stay 'you' even as you grow and change, but people can disagree about what makes you the same person.
key_concepts: Thoughts vs feelings (thinking something vs feeling something).
Dreams and imagination as mind activity, not 'fake' or 'real' in the same way as chairs and tables.
Memories as part of how you think of yourself.
Body changes vs feeling like 'the same me' over time.

micro_questions.name: different_feelings
micro_questions.prompt: Think about a time you felt very angry and a time you felt very calm. Were you still the same 'you' in both moments? What was different and what was the same?

micro_questions.name: old_memory
micro_questions.prompt: Remember something from when you were much younger. Does it feel like it happened to 'you', even though you are different now? Why?

micro_questions.name: dream_vs_real
micro_questions.prompt: Think of a dream that felt very real. How did you know it was a dream when you woke up? What changed?

guided_questions: When you say 'I', what do you usually meanâ??your body, your thoughts, your feelings, or something else?
Have you ever felt two different feelings at the same time (for example, excited and nervous)? What was that like?
If your body changes a lot as you grow, what makes you feel like the same person inside?

silent_questions: Is the child talking more about thoughts, feelings, body, or memories?
Are they raising a personal identity question (same person over time) or a mindâ??world question (real vs dream)?
Which cultural or family ideas about self might be shaping this?

moves: Normalize all feelings as acceptable to talk about.
Avoid asking for details that feel too private; invite, don't push.
Reflect the child's way of talking about 'me' before introducing new terms.
templates: It makes sense that feeling {emotion} changed how you saw things. What stayed the same about you?
You described your memory in a very clear way. How does remembering it make you feel now?

reflection_prompts: Today, notice one time when your feeling changes but you still feel like the same 'you'. What happened?
Think of one memory that feels important to who you are. Why do you think it matters so much?
content.next_suggestion: Next, you can explore simple questions about 'mind and body'â??for example, how thoughts, feelings, and actions connectâ??and how that matters for responsibility.

practice.original_question: Why do I feel like a different person when I am angry?
practice.explanation: This question is mostly about feelings: how emotions show up, change, and affect how you see yourself and the world.
follow_up_prompts: When you feel the way you are asking about, where do you notice it most in your body?
Does this feeling stay the same, or does it come and go in waves?
Can you remember a time when you felt this way and then it changed? What helped it change?
How does this feeling affect the way you see yourself or other people in that moment?
